title: John 3:16 Quiz
description: Test your knowledge of the most famous verse in the Bible — John 3:16 — and its surrounding context in John chapter 3.

questions.question: According to John 3:16, what motivated God to give His only begotten Son?
options: He wanted to judge the world
questions.explanation: John 3:16 begins with 'For God so loved the world' — God's love for the world was the driving motivation behind the gift of His Son.

questions.question: What does John 3:16 say is the result for 'whosoever believeth in him'?
options: Should not perish, but have everlasting life
Should be free from all trouble
questions.correctAnswer: Should not perish, but have everlasting life
questions.explanation: The promise of John 3:16 is that believers shall not perish but have everlasting life — eternal salvation through faith in Christ.

questions.question: Who came to Jesus by night in John 3, prompting the conversation that includes John 3:16?
questions.explanation: John 3:1-2 tells us Nicodemus, a Pharisee and ruler of the Jews, came to Jesus by night. This conversation produced the famous John 3:16 verse.

questions.question: True or False: In John 3:16, the phrase 'only begotten Son' means Jesus was created by God.
questions.explanation: 'Only begotten' (Greek: monogenes) means unique, one-of-a-kind. It speaks of Jesus' unique relationship with the Father as God's one and only Son, not that He was created. Jesus is eternally God (John 1:1).

questions.question: What did Jesus tell Nicodemus a man must experience to see the kingdom of God?
questions.explanation: In John 3:3, Jesus answered Nicodemus: 'Except a man be born again, he cannot see the kingdom of God.' This is the doctrine of spiritual regeneration.

questions.question: According to John 3:17, why did God send His Son into the world?
options: That the world through him might be saved
questions.correctAnswer: That the world through him might be saved
questions.explanation: John 3:17 clarifies: 'For God sent not his Son into the world to condemn the world; but that the world through him might be saved.' The purpose was salvation, not condemnation.

questions.question: In John 3:14-15, what Old Testament event did Jesus compare to His own crucifixion?
options: Moses lifting up the serpent in the wilderness
Abraham offering Isaac on the altar
questions.correctAnswer: Moses lifting up the serpent in the wilderness
questions.explanation: Jesus said, 'As Moses lifted up the serpent in the wilderness, even so must the Son of man be lifted up' (John 3:14). Just as looking at the bronze serpent brought healing, looking to Christ in faith brings eternal life.

questions.question: True or False: John 3:16 promises that everyone in the world will automatically be saved.
questions.explanation: John 3:16 says 'whosoever believeth in him' — salvation is offered to all but received only through personal faith in Jesus Christ. It is not automatic or universal.

questions.question: What was Nicodemus' position among the Jews?
options: A Pharisee and ruler of the Jews
questions.correctAnswer: A Pharisee and ruler of the Jews
questions.explanation: John 3:1 identifies Nicodemus as 'a man of the Pharisees' and 'a ruler of the Jews,' meaning he was a member of the Sanhedrin, the Jewish ruling council.

questions.question: According to John 3:18, what is the condition of the person who does not believe in Jesus?
questions.explanation: John 3:18 states: 'He that believeth not is condemned already, because he hath not believed in the name of the only begotten Son of God.' Unbelief leaves a person in a state of condemnation.

questions.question: True or False: Nicodemus initially understood what Jesus meant by 'born again.'
questions.explanation: Nicodemus was confused, asking 'How can a man be born when he is old? can he enter the second time into his mother's womb?' (John 3:4). He took it literally rather than spiritually.

questions.question: In John 3:5, Jesus said a man must be born of what two things to enter the kingdom of God?
questions.explanation: Jesus answered: 'Except a man be born of water and of the Spirit, he cannot enter into the kingdom of God' (John 3:5). This speaks of spiritual cleansing and regeneration by the Holy Spirit.

questions.question: What does the word 'perish' in John 3:16 refer to?
questions.explanation: 'Perish' in John 3:16 refers to eternal spiritual death — permanent separation from God. In contrast, 'everlasting life' is eternal fellowship with God through faith in Christ.

questions.question: Complete this verse: 'For God so loved the world, that he gave his only begotten ___.'
questions.explanation: John 3:16 (KJV): 'For God so loved the world, that he gave his only begotten Son, that whosoever believeth in him should not perish, but have everlasting life.'

questions.question: According to John 3:19-20, why do some people reject the light (Jesus)?
options: Because their deeds are evil and they love darkness
Because they have never heard the gospel
Because they are not intelligent enough
Because God has not chosen them
questions.correctAnswer: Because their deeds are evil and they love darkness
questions.explanation: John 3:19-20 explains: 'Men loved darkness rather than light, because their deeds were evil. For every one that doeth evil hateth the light.' Rejection of Christ is a moral issue, not an intellectual one.
